blocks.value: Saint Thérèse of Lisieux, known as the 'Little Flower,' was a Carmelite nun who discovered a 'little way' of spiritual childhood—doing small things with extraordinary love for God.

Thérèse taught that sanctity is not about great deeds but about complete surrender to God's will in everyday life. She wrote: 'My vocation is love... In the heart of the Church, I will be love.' Her path of trust and abandonment is accessible to all.

She died of tuberculosis at age 24 in 1897. Her autobiography, 'Story of a Soul,' became a worldwide bestseller. She promised to 'spend my heaven doing good on earth' and is invoked for countless miracles. She was declared a Doctor of the Church in 1997.
